item.title: That Surprise Splinter Cell-Like From Last Yearâ€™s Xbox Showcase Might Be In Trouble
item.content:encoded:
During last yearâ€™s Xbox Games Showcase, Korea-based developer EVR Studio announced Mudang: Two Hearts, a stealth action-adventure game with a notable resemblance to the Splinter Cell series. Now, the teamâ€™s website appears offline, and reports hint at possible layoffs in the past few months.

As reported by Need4Games, EVR allegedly laid off multiple people due to a lack of funding. The claim is based on a Korean tracking site, which shows the number of employees decreasing from over a hundred to just 22 as of the time of publication.

In addition, sources speaking to Need4Games were reportedly negative about the studioâ€™s situation, with one of the investors of EVR Studio reportedly saying that Mudang is meant to be released by the end of March 2026, which is also the end of the current fiscal year. â€œIf we donâ€™t receive it, the investors will be very upset with the situation, then it will be their meeting,â€ reads the report.

The outlet also reported a sudden silence in terms of online presence. EVRâ€™s official website currently leads to an error message when accessed, and on The Wayback Machine, the latest backups of the site are dated October 23. Over at the studioâ€™s YouTube channel, the last developer diaryâ€”which presented a motion-matching showcaseâ€”was uploaded back on August 15, and there have been no more updates since.

On LinkedIn, there are at least 34 people associated with the EVR Studio company profile, although several of those profiles are private. All the public profiles, including those of CEO Yongki Yoon, co-founder, director, and executive producer Dong joon Min, art director Bryan ku, and UI designer Jihong Lee, showcase â€œpresentâ€ in the respective Experience tabs of their profile, indicating they are still employed at the company.

EVR also has a Discord server, which shows over 2,300 members at the time of publication. As of now, the general chat channel is filled with people speculating about the state of the game based on the aforementioned reports, seemingly without an official response from the developer. The latest update, shared via a behind-the-scenes channel, was issued back on August 29.

Back then, EVR said all development divisions were focused on validating the playable build to ensure stability, running regression testing and balance tuning. The team also added that the following dev diary update may experience a slight delay because of these tests. â€œOur team is fully committed to delivering a level of quality that will be recognized by players worldwide, and we look forward to sharing the next stage of progress with you soon,â€ reads the Discord message.

Mudang: Two Hearts is slated to launch in 2026 on PC, PS5, and Xbox consoles. According to EVR, the game hit 100,000 wishlists by July 25 of last year.

Kotaku has reached out to EVR Studio for comment.



https://kotaku.com/mudang-two-hearts-splinter-cell-layoffs-shut-down-release-date-2000656736

item.title: Some Anthem Players Say EA Is Already Blocking Them From Playing The Game A Week Before It Shuts Down
item.content:encoded:
Weâ€™re just one week away from Electronic Arts shutting down Anthem, BioWareâ€™s questionable 2019 looter shooter detour that failed to take off and never got the second chance the RPG studio had promised. According to the initial announcement, fans who bought the game would still be able to play it up until it finally goes offline forever on January 12. However, as the end date gets closer, some players who are trying to go take their Javelins out for one last spin have discovered theyâ€™re no longer able to open the game.

We first took notice of this after seeing a few posts on X from users with screenshots showing that they were no longer able to download Anthem after previously purchasing it at some point over the past seven years. The EA app instead told them they â€œdonâ€™t ownâ€ the game. I asked around and a friend who had the game through the EA Play subscription tried to download it to his PC and was told â€œthis game is no longer offered in our catalog.â€

Anthem is shutting down for good in a week, so I thought I'd play one more time.

The EA App won't even let me download it even though I own it. pic.twitter.com/spVNJd9six

â€” DansGaming (@Dansgaming) January 5, 2026

As others have also reported, EA won't let me download Anthem, even though it shuts down a week from nowâ€¦ No "last hurrah" I guess. Crazy that I bought the game and can't even download it while it's still, allegedly, aliveâ€¦ pic.twitter.com/cRu0s4DU1N

â€” Luke Stephens (@LukeStephens) January 5, 2026

However, this doesnâ€™t seem to be a universal issue, as Kotakuâ€™s Ethan Gach was able to download without issue from the EA Play app. 

Whatever the case may be, it seems like at least some Anthem players who may have wanted to give the game one last try before BioWare and EA needlessly send it tumbling down into a digital void arenâ€™t able to now. The mech shooter hasnâ€™t  been available for purchase since the original shutdown announcement back in July, but if you had a copy of it in your library or on a disc, you were supposed to have one more week to play it.

Weâ€™ve reached out to EA and BioWare for comment on the situation, and will update this story if we hear back. This whole thing couldâ€™ve been avoided if BioWare had made Anthem accessible offline, but the studio claims it â€œwas designed to be an online-only title.â€ Thatâ€™s in contrast to other failed live-service gambits like Redfall and Suicide Squad: Kill the Justice League, both of which received offline modes before being sent off to pasture.



https://kotaku.com/anthem-shutdown-download-bioware-ea-pc-app-play-2000656725

item.title: Guy Behind Viral â€˜Focus, Mâ€™ Gaming Meme Never Expected It To Spread So Fast
item.content:encoded:
Late last month, an old video showing off what a hypothetical AAA Mario game would look like went viral after two voice actors added new dialogue styled after that in blockbuster games like Uncharted and Gears of War. Now, a few weeks later, one line from the game, â€œFocus, M,â€ has spread across all corners of the web, annoying some and leading to a lot of online discourse.

On December 23, voice actor Ryan Stewart uploaded a video featuring himself as Mario and another voice actor, Ariel Hack, as Peach, talking to each other over comms as the famous plumber approaches Bowserâ€™s castle. The original gameplay video featured in Stewartâ€™s post was created by Funkyzeit as a conceptual mock-up of what a AAA Mario game might look like, and was shared online back in 2022. This new version, featuring dialogue perfectly parodying how some AAA games deliver narrative and tutorial information, quickly went viral online, with Stewartâ€™s Twitter upload reaching over 25 million views as of January 5.

I had no idea AAA Mario would be so popular. I had to make some more. ğŸ„
ft. @ArielHck as Peach https://t.co/p3YMlF5rEn pic.twitter.com/ggarxptMuZ

â€” Ryan Stewart (@RyanStewartVO) December 21, 2025

Quickly, one phrase from the video became popular: â€œFocus, M.â€ This line is delivered by Hackâ€™s Peach after Mario makes a joke. Itâ€™s a pitch-perfect replication of the kind of AAA video game dialogue that was so prevalent in blockbuster single-player games from the Xbox 360 and PS4 generations, and which can still be found in some bigger games now. All of this dialogue, including the â€œFocus, Mâ€ line, was written by Stewart himself, who told Kotaku that while he didnâ€™t expect the bit to go as viral as it has, he knew he had a â€œbangerâ€ on his hands once he heard it.

â€œAs I was writing the dialogue, I knew it was funny,â€ said Stewart via email. â€œOnce I got Arielâ€™s reads in, though, I knew it would be a banger. That being said, the sheer amount of discussion it spawned after the fact was unexpected.â€

When asked for his thoughts on how â€œFocus, Mâ€ has become its own meme, with people using it who havenâ€™t even seen the original video, Stewart told Kotaku:  â€œIf nothing else, I think itâ€™s resulted in some excellent fan art! I hope my future posts can do the same.â€

While Stewart is pretty positive about â€œFocus, M,â€ some online arenâ€™t. The original creator behind the AAA Mario video never replied to Kotakuâ€™s request for comment, but did like a YouTube comment left by someone comparing them to Oppenheimer, the man who created the nuclear bomb. That seems to indicate that, at the very least, Funkyzeit has mixed feelings about their involvement in â€œFocus, M.â€

Meanwhile, online, the â€œFocus, Mâ€ meme has rapidly evolved and spread. You can find people applying it to basically anything at this point. New Marathon graphics? Thatâ€™s a â€œFocus, Mâ€ game. PS1 platformer Croc? Thatâ€™s a â€œFocus, Mâ€ game. Starfield? Sure, whatever, thatâ€™s a â€œFocus, Mâ€ game, too.

At this point, the meme has already run its course and lost all meaning. Itâ€™s like people calling anything they donâ€™t like slop. And you can find plenty of posts from people saying they feel the meme is dead already. Iâ€™m not so sure, though. I still regularly see people tagging new AAA games and remasters as â€œFocus, Mâ€ games. And I suspect that at least a few devs have been watching all of this and are possibly making some tweaks to dialogue in their own upcoming games. I feel certain that at least one game has likely removed or cut a line that asked the player to â€œFocusâ€¦â€ in response to all of this.



https://kotaku.com/guy-behind-viral-focus-m-gaming-meme-never-expected-it-to-spread-so-fast-2000656706
item.dc:creator: invalid@example.com (ResetEra_Newsbot

item.title: Stranger Things Fans Are Convinced Thereâ€™s A Secret Episode That Will â€˜Fixâ€™ Disappointing Finale
item.content:encoded:
Stranger Thingsâ€™ series finale continues to be a lightning rod for controversy. While plenty of people were fine with how the Netflix horror series wrapped up after a decade, thereâ€™s a loud subset of fans who are taking to the digital streets to tear it down, say awful things about the people who worked on it, and declare it the next Game of Thrones-level failure. Another fraction of that group, however, is holding onto a bizarre sliver of hope with the belief that perhaps the disappointing conclusion is not all it seems. The movement, which is calling itself Conformity Gate, has gathered â€œevidenceâ€ indicating that the events depicted in the finale are actually an illusion and that there is still a battle left to fight, which will play out in a secret episode thatâ€™s not available on Netflix right now.

Obviously, weâ€™ll be discussing the fifth season of Stranger Things here, so if you want to stay spoiler free, you should leave now. (Really, you probably shouldnâ€™t have opened this article to begin with.) But the tl;dr of the theory is that the sterile and rushed nature of the finale is an intentional creative choice meant to reflect that it takes place in a distorted reality created by Vecna and everyone in the show is â€œconformingâ€ to it. 

Admittedly, I fully planned to just roll my eyes at all this pretty wild speculation because I lived through the Mass Effect 3 ending controversy and the Indoctrination Theory, which fans believed explained that gameâ€™s finale as a hallucination but was really just a way for them to cope with not liking the way things turned out. But, I donâ€™t know, thereâ€™s some compelling evidence in the theory, both based on whatâ€™s in the show and on how Netflix and show creators the Duffer Brothers have talked about it since. 

Many of these details are subtle, such as the way that characters sit during the graduation scene resembling how villain Vecna sits at other points in the series, whereas others seem to be pretty overt, like Max calling out Mikeâ€™s D&D epilogue for being too comforting, as if something is off. Hereâ€™s one of the quicker rundowns I could find, by @meechski on TikTok, but you can also find much lengthier breakdowns on YouTube.

Also, as someone in the comments of that video points out, if you search â€œconformity gateâ€ or â€œfake endingâ€ on Netflix, Stranger Things is the only search result for the latter, and one of two for the former alongside Emily in Paris. Make of that what you will.

I donâ€™t know that any one thing made me a full-blown believer, but taken all together, it was enough for me to at least become interested in seeing if it actually pans out. Conspiracy theories usually have at least some shred of plausibility that allows them to gain some traction, but they also tend to be made up of a lot of square pegs shoved into round holes. All these pieces of evidence could just be coincidences born of bad writing and desperation. 

guysâ€¦ notice how all of them are reading WHITE scripts when shawn levy confirmed the finale was printed on RED scriptsâ€¦ they are trying to confuse us with that trailer. i AM sure #confirmitygate pic.twitter.com/Pje0LF13dm

â€” Ê…ÇÉ¯ | à©ˆâœ©â€§â‚ŠËš (@melinastapes) January 5, 2026

Luckily, we wonâ€™t really have to wait long for these hopes to be shattered, as the entire theory hinges on this hypothetical secret finale premiering on January 7, when Netflix is planning to announce something about its 2026 programming. Of course, I donâ€™t want any Stranger Things fans to have to suffer a worse ending than the one theyâ€™d hoped for, but after witnessing the behavior of some members of the community in the wake of a disappointing finale, Iâ€™m also wondering if those who have said some truly heinous things about the people who worked on this show even deserve a better ending.



https://kotaku.com/stranger-things-secret-finale-conformity-gate-explained-2000656704
item.dc:creator: invalid@example.com (ResetEra_Newsbot

item.title: Vampire Survivors Remade In Hytale Shows Why So Many Players Are Hyped For The Minecraft Rival
item.content:encoded:
Hypixel Studios, developer of the Minecraft-inspired survival game Hytale, has shown the sandbox gameâ€™s modding capabilities with a Vampire Survivors-like prototype that has fans excited ahead of the gameâ€™s Early Access launch later this month. In a social media post over the weekend, Hypixel co-founder Simon Collins-Laflamme shared a 40-second gameplay clip showcasing a character fending off voxel-based hordes of enemies in a top-down view arena.

According to Collins-Laflamme, the video shows a Hytale mod created by a team member in their spare time, and itâ€™s intended as a proof-of-concept demo for â€œhow different genresâ€ could be realized within the game by fans and modders.

The following video showcases a server-side Hytale mod created by a Hytale team member in their spare time. Itâ€™s intended purely as inspiration for how different genres could be realized within Hytale!

The gameplay shown represents only a small subset of our moddingâ€¦ pic.twitter.com/YaszQv9kDb

â€” Simon (@Simon_Hypixel) January 4, 2026

â€œThe gameplay shown represents only a small subset of our modding capabilities and was used to build a simple, survivor-like experience,â€ Collins-Laflamme wrote. While the mod is not planned for release as part of the game, Hypixel â€œmay publish it â€“ or similar examples â€“ as reference material for the community.â€

The video comes less than two months after Hypixel reacquired the rights to Hytale from League of Legends maker Riot Games, which had previously canceled the project in June of last year. The team released a 16-minute gameplay trailer shortly afterwards, but the latest clip is focused on Hytaleâ€™s potential to be a springboard for user-generated content like the Mojang hit that inspired it.

Hytale is gearing up for Early Access

â€œMy prediction is, it will do very well initially and then it will slow down until the modders / servers and us start to release some major content and then it will keep growing for years to come. Especially as we add more modding tools and options,â€ Collins-Laflamme wrote on X, responding to a user who suggested that Hytaleâ€™s release â€œwill probably be something huge.â€

The reply came from a larger thread in which the co-founder expressed feeling â€œangerâ€ as the studio gets closer to the early access launch of this new version of Hytale, which is slated for January 13. According to Collins-Laflamme, thatâ€™s due to pouring four years of engineering into rebuilding the gameâ€™s engine rather than working on gameplay features. In his eyes, that leaves the team with a â€œfour-year gap and a lot of catching up to do,â€ alongside a rebuilt engine that is â€œnever gonna be used.â€

As previously stated by the developer in a FAQ, the sandbox wonâ€™t be available on Steam at launch in order to focus on its existing community. Thatâ€™s to avoid chasing â€œa flood of cold first impressions that could overcorrect the gameâ€™s direction.â€ Hypixel explained that while it doesnâ€™t shy away from â€œhonest, negative criticism,â€ the team is more interested in feedback from players who are already familiar with the gameâ€™s development background.

Most importantly, the FAQ notes that Steam â€œcurrently doesnâ€™t supportâ€ some of Hytaleâ€™s modding features, and that the developer â€œwill be in contact with Valve in the near futureâ€ to try and fix that. Otherwise it might be a while before Steam users get to recreate the platformâ€™s latest hits inside Hytale.



https://kotaku.com/hytale-vampire-survivors-mod-early-access-steam-minecraft-2000656708
